key_insight: Reducing the information gap between privileged expert demonstrations and sensor-only student observations (visibility and uncertainty differences) substantially improves closed-loop imitation performance in simulated end-to-end driving.
problem_solved: Imitation-learned driving policies trained on privileged expert data fail in closed-loop because experts see and know more (ignore occlusions, have low uncertainty) than student agents that rely on raw sensors, causing a learner–expert asymmetry and poor real-world robustness.
method: Quantify and analyze the visibility and uncertainty gaps between privileged experts and sensor-based students in simulation.

Minimize learner–expert asymmetry by aligning expert demonstrations to student inputs—e.g., introducing occlusions/noise and stochasticity to expert signals and using uncertainty-aware training objectives.
Evaluate aligned training in closed-loop driving scenarios to show improved robustness compared to standard imitation baselines.
impact: Provides a practical recipe for making simulator-generated expert data more useful for sensor-based end-to-end driving policies—leading to more reliable closed-loop behavior and faster transfer from simulation to realistic deployment.
visual_elements: Side-by-side schematic: privileged expert view vs. sensor-only student view (highlighting occlusions and hidden state).
Pipeline diagram showing 'Simulator expert → Asymmetry reduction (occlusion/noise/uncertainty) → Student training → Closed-loop evaluation'.

paper_title: LEAD: Minimizing Learner-Expert Asymmetry in End-to-End Driving
paper_authors: Long Nguyen, Micha Fauth, Bernhard Jaeger, Daniel Dauner, Maximilian Igl
